chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's clear that these three points are missing in Ratramnus's section 52.

He openly acknowledges, when explaining the words of Saint Ambrose, that the bread of life, which came down from heaven, is received by us at the altar. He speaks clearly about the spiritual nourishment by which the faithful are nurtured in the Church, the food that believers receive, and he teaches that the bread and wine not only can, but actually do, give us eternal life. This living bread that came down from heaven provides the substance of eternal life. He states that in the Eucharist, what is perceptible to the senses or tangible can only nourish the body, but not the soul in any way. This is so true that among all Catholics, it is beyond any shadow of a doubt. This reasoning strongly proves that those who believed there was no symbolism in the Eucharist, thinking everything was open and clear manifestation, are greatly mistaken.

Ratramnus never said that the life contained in the mystery comes from the invisible power of the word, which produces faith. The speaker forgot that Ratramnus criticized the notion of the mystery being enacted spiritually because the spirit of faith accomplishes it. Indeed, if Ratramnus said that faith makes the mystery, by what right can one claim that the life within the mystery creates or produces faith? Whichever way the speaker turns, it's not easy to escape this dilemma. For if Ratramnus's intention is that faith makes the mystery, it's wrongly accused of making the mystery produce faith. However, he was far from such subtleties, as he fully acknowledges that the mystery of the Eucharist is accomplished by the power of the Spirit of God, which is the credible object of our faith or Christian persuasion. Nothing wiser or more orthodox than this doctrine of Ratramnus can be proposed.

Consequently, it is necessary not to have taught in this faith the efficacy and power of the body of Christ.

numero 52 occurrere. 1o Recognoscit aperte, explicans verba S. Ambrosii,
 panem vitae qui de coelo descendit, a nobis recipi
in altari; nam conceptis verbis loquitur de alimento

continetur; esse a verbi potentia invisibili, quae
fidem operatur. Excidit a memoria dissertatoris quod
exprobraverit Ratramno mysterium agi spiritualiter,
 quia fidei spiritus illud peragit. Enim vero si Ratramnus
dixit fidem efficere mysterium, quo jure
dicere potest vitam, quae in mysterio est, operari
seu efficere fidem? In quamcunque partem se dederit
dissertator, haud facile sese ab hoc laqueo expediet. Nam si mens Ratramni sit fidem efficere mysterium,
perperam ei exprobatur mysterium efficere
fidem: caeterum longe abfuit ab ejusmodi subtilitatibus;
quippe cum affatim recognoscat virtute Spiritus
Dei effieri mysterium Eucharistiae, quod est fidei
nostrae seu suasionis Christianorum objectum credibile. Nihil hac Ratramni doctrina sapientius aut magis

in hac fide efficientiam, ac virtutem corporis

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
On the other hand, it's argued that this bread contains a life not visible to the eyes, but recognized only through faith. This bread has come down from heaven, and it is said that whoever eats of this bread will become immortal. Therefore, within this bread lies a life that isn't seen by the physical eyes but is perceived through faith. This is the living bread that descended from heaven, and it is truly said: Whoever eats this will never die; it is the body of Christ.

Who would be convinced that these words imply the efficiency and power of the body of Christ are understood within this faith? Just as eyes are said to see colors and light, without containing their effectiveness: saying that faith perceives or believes in the mystery of the body of Christ, viewed through the eyes of faith, is not to claim that the efficiency and power of the body of Christ lie in this faith. However, I fear that in this discussion, it might be too contentious to claim complete victory. Socrates, Ecclesiastical History, Book 3, Chapter 18, Page 633.

When he denies that Christ is physically on the altar (as noted by the commentator on page 178 of the Paris edition, and page 292, number 178, of the Amsterdam edition, and page 178, first Paris edition), and insists it should be understood spiritually, he reveals in number 76: Just as in the mystery, that bread is taken as the body, so too in the mystery, the members of the people believing in Christ are represented. And just as that bread is called the body of believers not physically, but spiritually, so it is necessary to understand the body of Christ not physically, but spiritually.

 non apparet oculis corporeis, sed fidei contuetur

fidei contuetur aspectu, non est dicere in hac fide
consistere efficaciam et virtutem corporis Christi. Sed vereor ne in hac causa sit ὐπερ νικᾶν ἐπιφθώνον
nimis vincere invidiosum (Socrates, Histor. Eccl. lib. III, lit. M., cap. 18, pag. 633). XXII. Corporaliter cum negat esse Christum in altari

pag. 292, num. 178, edit. Amstelod., et pag. 178,
edit. 1 Paris. ), ac spiritualiter ait intelligi oportere,
